results.title: Lamb: the story of the fat lamb industry in Australia
results.creator_credit: John Heyer, Australian National Film Board and James Pearson
results.brief_description: The extent of fat lamb breeding throughout Australia is shown - crossbreeding - types of sheep. Sale yards and weir at Yarrawonga; lectures on feed growing and crossbreeding results are shown at Rutherglen Experiment Farm; sale markets, butchering and chilling. Produced to show the care, cleanliness and scientific production of the best fat lamb for the dinner tables of Britain.

results.title: Lamb Roast [advertisement]
results.brief_description:
Naomi Watts stars in this commercial as the girl that wins a date with Tom Cruise but turns it down so she can be at home for one of her Mum’s lamb roasts.
Produced by Campaign Palace.

results.title: Lamb for world market
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: A thriving industry in Western Australia is the production of lambs for the meat export trade. These lambs, which are slaughtered at 16 weeks, are specially bred for the purpose. They are yarded and sent to Fremantle. Great care is taken to prevent injury. After slaughtering, the carcases are carefully inspected, then graded and passed through various processes until they reach the freezing chamber. From there they are taken as expeditiously as possible to the ships which transport them to the United Kingdom, USA, Canada and Hong Kong.

results.title: Lalai dreamtime
results.creator_credit: Australia Council. Aboriginal Arts Board and Michael Edols
results.brief_description: Lalai Dreamtime is a reconstruction of the traditional way of Aboriginal life - in particular, the transmission of knowledge and culture from one generation to the next, enacted by the Woolagoodjah family of north-west Australia. An old man takes his son to a sacred place to explain about their ancestors. He outlines the foundation of Aboriginal mythology when humankind was prepared to accommodate to nature rather than change nature for the sake of humankind, and the fundamental and intimate connection between the Aboriginal people and their land. Esben Storm acted as editor on this multi-award winning film. With some Australian Aboriginal language with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australia Council. Aboriginal Arts Board and Michael Edols

results.title: Lakme
results.creator_credit: Cheryl Forrest-Smith, John Charles and ABC Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian Opera”.
The 1976 performance of Leo Delibes “Lakme” at the Sydney Opera House stars Joan Sutherland, Huguette Tourangeau and Henri Wilden. The story is set in India in the mid 19th Century when the British were imposing a suppressive rule over the many religious sects. Nilakantha, the leader of one of the forbidden sects is secretly raising his daughter Lakme as a priestess to be worshipped as Divine by his followers. He keeps her isolated in a temple which he has surrounded with a bamboo stockade, declaring the temple and garden to be sacred ground. Sung in French. No subtitles. A brief summary of the plot is provided on screen in English at the beginning of each Act. Performers include: Joan Sutherland, Clifford Grant, Huguette Tourangeau, Graeme Ewer, Henri Wilden. The Australian Opera (Sydney) conducted by Richard Bonynge. The Elizabethan Orchestra (Sydney) conducted by Robert Ingram. Geoffrey Arnold (Chorus Master), Australian Opera Chorus. Staged by Michael Kaempff

results.title: Lakes, rivers and other water sources
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Journal Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Natural Phenomena Series”.
Investigates the earth’s major sources of fresh water (lakes, rivers and underground water). The origins of this water, the action of rivers, how lakes clog up, the forces that create the underground water supply and the way in which these major sources of fresh water are interconnected are also considered. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Lake Maracaibo
results.creator_credit: Shell, Unidad Filmica and Boris Woronzow
results.brief_description: For centuries Lake Maracaibo, on the north-western coast of Venezuela, and the surrounding countryside have been the home of fishermen and shepherds. Today with the discovery of oil, swampland and savanna are being converted into industrial sites and residential districts.

results.title: Lake
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Baker, Stephen Ramsey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Little world of Dietmar Fill”.
Dietmar focuses on a small freshwater lake near his home in the Blue Mountains west of Sydney. He explores the life of the lake and expresses his concern for the likely impact of pollution on its ecology. Narrated by Robyn Williams.
